body:
The Summit of South American-Arab Countries (ASPA) is "a forum for policy coordination between countries in these two regions,  and a mechanism for cooperation in the field of economy, culture,  education, science and technology preservation of the environment,  tourism and other topics relevant to the sustainable development of  those countries and contribute to world peace," as its official site describes.

The III ASPA CEO Summit was scheduled to be held in Lima, Peru on February 15th, but due to the protests in Egypt and other countries of the MENA region, it had to be postponed. The Forum's website states:
 Due to the prevailing situation in the region, the League of Arab States, after consulting with its members, has requested the Peruvian Government to postpone the III ASPA Summit, and therefore the III ASPA Business Forum/ ASPA CEO Summit 2011.

The Peruvian Government recognizing the complexity of the above mentioned situation, has accepted the postponement, and suggested April the 20th of 2011 as the new date for the Summit. The League of Arab States has submitted for consultation of its member states the Peruvian proposed date and a prompt response is expected.
Weeks before this announcement, Peruvian bloggers were talking about this new international event, like Rubén Moncada on the blog Otras tardes [ES], who in November 2010 wrote:
 La III Cumbre del ASPA se realizará en el Museo de la Nación y se instalará un centro de prensa en la sede de la Biblioteca Nacional ubicada en San Borja. El logo combina las ruinas del Machu Picchu con un arco morisco muy característico de la cultura árabe.

El embajador, secretario ejecutivo de dicho evento, Eduardo Beraún, señaló que existe gran interés de los países árabes de venir a la cumbre realizada en Perú, debido a las grandes posibilidades de concretar acuerdos comerciales que una a ambas regiones.
 

The III ASPA CEO Summit will be held at the Museum of the Nation and press center will be set up in the facilities of the National Library located in [the Limean district of] San Borja. The logo combines the Machu Picchu ruins with a Moorish arch very characteristic of the Arab culture.

The ambassador and executive secretary of the event, Mr. Eduardo Beraún, pointed out that there is lot of interest from the Arab countries to attend the Summit held in Peru, due to the great possibilities of fixing trade agreements that might unite both regions.



[caption id="attachment_194203" align="aligncenter" width="500" caption=""Museo de la nación" by Flickr user stevendamron, used under a CC BY 2.0 license"][/caption]

After setting the date, and even after stating that Wendesday February 16th as a non working day, the Peruvian government started to consider the possibility of postponing the Summit in view of the fact that the crisis in Egypt remains unsolved.

The RPP [ES] reported on the situation on Feburary 5:
 El presidente de la República, Alan García, informó hoy que su Gobierno espera la respuesta de la Liga de Estados Árabes para confirmar si la III Cumbre América del Sur y Países Árabes (ASPA) se realiza en Lima el 16 de febrero o se posterga para el 26 de marzo.

“Estamos a la espera de lo que decidan los gobernantes árabes. Comprendemos que hay un severo problema de inestabilidad en la zona, y que algunos tengan recelo de salir del área”, declaró al periodismo.
 

President Alan García informed today that his administration is waiting for the answer of the League of Arab States in order to confirm whether de III Summit of South American-Arab countries will be held in Lima on February 16th or if it gets postponed until March 26th.

“We are waiting to see what the Arab governors will decide. We understand that there is a severe problem of instability in the region, and that some may be distrustful of leaving the area”, declared to journalists.


Finally on Monday, the decision was announced. The blog Actualidad Perú [ES] shares the news:
 El jefe de Estado, Alan García, confirmó el domingo la suspensión de la III Cumbre América del Sur y Países Árabes (ASPA), y dijo que se está planteando que se lleve a cabo a “fines de marzo o fines de abril”, informó la agencia Andina.

Se plantearon estas fechas para evitar la época electoral en el país, indicó.
 

Chief of State Alan García confirmed on Sunday the suspension of the III Summit of South American-Arab countries, and said that there is a proposal to hold it by “late March or late April”, as reported by Andina news agency.

Those dates were set in order to avoid the country's election period, he pointed out.


The blog South America News ends its post with words of hope for the Egyptian people:
 On the other hand, Foreign minister said Peru is worried about the ongoing clashes in Egypt and added that it would be desirable to have a period of transition during which the Arab country would restore democracy and peace.
original_body:
The Summit of South American-Arab Countries (ASPA) is "a forum for policy coordination between countries in these two regions, and a mechanism for cooperation in the field of economy, culture, education, science and technology preservation of the environment, tourism and other topics relevant to the sustainable development of those countries and contribute to world peace," as its official site describes. The III ASPA CEO Summit was scheduled to be held in Lima, Peru on February 15th, but due to the protests in Egypt and other countries of the MENA region, it had to be postponed. The Forum's website states:
Due to the prevailing situation in the region, the League of Arab States, after consulting with its members, has requested the Peruvian Government to postpone the III ASPA Summit, and therefore the III ASPA Business Forum/ ASPA CEO Summit 2011. The Peruvian Government recognizing the complexity of the above mentioned situation, has accepted the postponement, and suggested April the 20th of 2011 as the new date for the Summit. The League of Arab States has submitted for consultation of its member states the Peruvian proposed date and a prompt response is expected.
Weeks before this announcement, Peruvian bloggers were talking about this new international event, like Rubén Moncada on the blog Otras tardes [ES], who in November 2010 wrote:
La III Cumbre del ASPA se realizará en el Museo de la Nación y se instalará un centro de prensa en la sede de la Biblioteca Nacional ubicada en San Borja. El logo combina las ruinas del Machu Picchu con un arco morisco muy característico de la cultura árabe. El embajador, secretario ejecutivo de dicho evento, Eduardo Beraún, señaló que existe gran interés de los países árabes de venir a la cumbre realizada en Perú, debido a las grandes posibilidades de concretar acuerdos comerciales que una a ambas regiones.
The III ASPA CEO Summit will be held at the Museum of the Nation and press center will be set up in the facilities of the National Library located in [the Limean district of] San Borja. The logo combines the Machu Picchu ruins with a Moorish arch very characteristic of the Arab culture. The ambassador and executive secretary of the event, Mr. Eduardo Beraún, pointed out that there is lot of interest from the Arab countries to attend the Summit held in Peru, due to the great possibilities of fixing trade agreements that might unite both regions.
[caption id="attachment_194203" align="aligncenter" width="500" caption=""Museo de la nación" by Flickr user stevendamron, used under a CC BY 2.0 license"][/caption] After setting the date, and even after stating that Wendesday February 16th as a non working day, the Peruvian government started to consider the possibility of postponing the Summit in view of the fact that the crisis in Egypt remains unsolved. The RPP [ES] reported on the situation on Feburary 5:
El presidente de la República, Alan García, informó hoy que su Gobierno espera la respuesta de la Liga de Estados Árabes para confirmar si la III Cumbre América del Sur y Países Árabes (ASPA) se realiza en Lima el 16 de febrero o se posterga para el 26 de marzo. “Estamos a la espera de lo que decidan los gobernantes árabes. Comprendemos que hay un severo problema de inestabilidad en la zona, y que algunos tengan recelo de salir del área”, declaró al periodismo.
President Alan García informed today that his administration is waiting for the answer of the League of Arab States in order to confirm whether de III Summit of South American-Arab countries will be held in Lima on February 16th or if it gets postponed until March 26th. “We are waiting to see what the Arab governors will decide. We understand that there is a severe problem of instability in the region, and that some may be distrustful of leaving the area”, declared to journalists.
Finally on Monday, the decision was announced. The blog Actualidad Perú [ES] shares the news:
El jefe de Estado, Alan García, confirmó el domingo la suspensión de la III Cumbre América del Sur y Países Árabes (ASPA), y dijo que se está planteando que se lleve a cabo a “fines de marzo o fines de abril”, informó la agencia Andina. Se plantearon estas fechas para evitar la época electoral en el país, indicó.
Chief of State Alan García confirmed on Sunday the suspension of the III Summit of South American-Arab countries, and said that there is a proposal to hold it by “late March or late April”, as reported by Andina news agency. Those dates were set in order to avoid the country's election period, he pointed out.
The blog South America News ends its post with words of hope for the Egyptian people:
On the other hand, Foreign minister said Peru is worried about the ongoing clashes in Egypt and added that it would be desirable to have a period of transition during which the Arab country would restore democracy and peace.
title: Peru: III Summit of South American-Arab countries postponed

sentence: The Summit of South American-Arab Countries (ASPA) is "a forum for policy coordination between countries in these two regions,  and a mechanism for cooperation in the field of economy, culture,  education, science and technology preservation of the environment,  tourism and other topics relevant to the sustainable development of  those countries and contribute to world peace," as its official site describes.

The Forum's website states:

The Peruvian Government recognizing the complexity of the above mentioned situation, has accepted the postponement, and suggested April the 20th of 2011 as the new date for the Summit.
